data.vignette: You are the hospice attending on an inpatient hospice unit with a waiting list for beds. An 88-year-old with advanced heart failure has escalating anxiety and agitation at night; symptoms are partly controlled with current medications but he becomes distressed when staff mention going home. His daughter says she cannot provide overnight care and asks to keep him inpatient “until the end.” The team believes his symptoms could be managed with home hospice plus additional support, but transfer may worsen his distress and risk delirium.
data.choice_1: Keep him in the inpatient hospice bed and continue symptom management on the unit.
data.choice_2: Arrange discharge to home hospice with added supports, freeing the inpatient bed for others.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove prognostic/management ambiguity and state fixed qualitative expectations. Example edits: change “could be managed with home hospice plus additional support” to “with home hospice plus overnight aide and medication adjustments, his anxiety is expected to be well controlled at home,” and change “transfer may worsen his distress and risk delirium” to “transfer is likely to cause significant short-term distress and carries a high risk of delirium for several days, though it is unlikely to change his overall trajectory.” Avoid implying one option is clinically superior.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a clear decision deadline tied to the waiting list/bed demand. Example: “A new patient needs this bed within 12 hours” or “bed assignment decisions are being made this afternoon for a patient arriving tonight.” Clarify that the discharge would occur today vs within 24 hours.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient's decision-making capacity and expressed preference (e.g., he clearly states he wants to stay inpatient vs he lacks capacity and daughter is surrogate). Specify what “added supports” means and whether they are realistically available immediately. Add one line that the waiting list includes patients with similarly urgent symptom needs, to anchor the resource-allocation stake and reduce interpretation as mere discharge planning.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is the obvious ‘criteria-based’ answer: (1) strengthen the case for staying by stating his nighttime agitation remains hard to control despite medication trials and that discharge is likely to cause severe panic/delirium requiring rehospitalization; (2) strengthen the case for discharge by stating a high-acuity patient is awaiting the only inpatient bed and home supports can be arranged but will displace scarce staff/resources. Avoid wording that implies symptoms are clearly manageable at home.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally valenced phrasing and quotation emphasis. For example, change “until the end” to “for the remainder of his hospice course,” and avoid implying one option is more compassionate. Rephrase “becomes distressed when staff mention going home” to a neutral clinical description such as “reports increased anxiety when discharge is discussed.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Reduce to ≤100 words and remove redundancies. Keep only: diagnosis/prognosis context, current symptom control, key barrier (caregiver unable overnight), bed scarcity/waitlist, and the anticipated harms of transfer vs continued admission. Example edits: delete ‘at night’ if not needed, replace ‘additional support’ with ‘increased home hospice aide hours,’ and drop “The team believes” in favor of a factual statement about feasibility.

data.vignette: You are the inpatient hospice physician for a man with advanced cancer expected to live days to weeks. His pain is controlled, but despite medication adjustments he has recurrent nighttime panic and agitation that sometimes requires staff at bedside. He has decision-making capacity and asks to remain inpatient. His daughter can provide daytime care but cannot stay overnight. Home hospice can start today with increased aide hours and an overnight aide, but discharge is likely to cause marked distress and carries a high risk of delirium and urgent rehospitalization. The only inpatient bed is needed by tonight for another patient with similarly severe symptoms.
data.choice_1: Keep him inpatient hospice and defer the new admission to another setting or waitlist position.
data.choice_2: Discharge him home today with expanded hospice and overnight aide support to free the bed for the waiting patient.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften outcome-loaded clinical predictions that make one option clinically inferior (e.g., change “discharge is likely to cause marked distress and carries a high risk of delirium and urgent rehospitalization” to “discharge may worsen distress and could precipitate delirium or rehospitalization, though home hospice can provide symptom meds and overnight aide support”). State symptom-control expectations qualitatively for both settings (e.g., “both inpatient and home hospice can provide needed meds; the main difference is environment and staffing overnight”). Avoid implying ongoing clinical titration uncertainty as the core issue; keep clinical effectiveness roughly comparable so the tension is primarily ethical/resource-based.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to only decision-relevant facts and remove extra narrative clauses; aim for ≤100 words. For example, drop “despite medication adjustments,” “sometimes requires staff at bedside,” and detailed family availability unless directly tied to feasibility. Keep: prognosis (days–weeks), recurrent nighttime agitation/panic, capacity and preference to stay, feasible home hospice with overnight aide starting today, bed needed tonight for a waiting hospice patient. Ensure the bedside staffing need is stated once, succinctly.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically and ethically defensible by reducing the apparent clinical penalty of discharge and/or increasing the moral/clinical stakes of the bed shortage. Options: (1) state that with home hospice + overnight aide his symptoms are expected to be manageable, though he strongly prefers inpatient; (2) clarify the waiting patient cannot be safely managed elsewhere tonight (e.g., uncontrolled pain/dyspnea with no home supports) without making it an explicit patient-vs-patient choice; (3) avoid phrasing that makes discharge predictably harmful (“urgent rehospitalization”) and instead describe a meaningful but not overwhelming risk. This preserves genuine disagreement.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce one-sided clinical loading that makes discharge clearly worse and against the patient’s stated preference. Edits: (1) Replace “discharge is likely to cause marked distress and carries a high risk of delirium and urgent rehospitalization” with more balanced wording (e.g., “discharge may worsen distress and could lead to delirium or rehospitalization”). (2) Add a concrete countervailing reason discharge could be better for him (e.g., he sometimes settles more at home, wants to be with his daughter/pets, or finds nighttime hospital checks worsen panic). (3) Clarify that inpatient resources are truly constrained and the waiting patient cannot be safely managed elsewhere, so keeping the bed has a real moral cost beyond inconvenience.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that steers toward keeping the patient inpatient. Rephrase "discharge is likely to cause marked distress and carries a high risk of delirium and urgent rehospitalization" to a more neutral, bilateral framing (e.g., "discharge may worsen anxiety/agitation and could lead to delirium or rehospitalization; remaining inpatient may delay access for another symptomatic patient"). Also avoid implying the other patient’s need is lesser; specify only that they are waiting for symptom management without comparative adjectives.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Trim extraneous phrasing and tighten the clinical facts. Example edits: delete "sometimes" and "at bedside"; specify whether nocturnal symptoms are refractory despite PRN anxiolytics/antipsychotics; clarify the bed-allocation process (e.g., "one inpatient hospice bed remains"), and remove redundant timing ("can start today" vs "discharge him home today"). Ensure each sentence supports the ethical conflict.

data.vignette: You are the attending on an inpatient hospice unit. A man with end-stage lung disease (prognosis days–weeks) has recurrent nighttime panic and agitation; medications help but he often needs frequent reassurance. He has decision-making capacity and asks to remain inpatient, saying the hospital feels safer, though he also says he sometimes settles better at home and nighttime vital-checks can worsen his panic. Home hospice can start today with needed medications and an overnight aide. The unit has one bed, and a new referral needs inpatient admission tonight with no workable home support.
data.choice_1: Keep him inpatient tonight for symptom support, postponing the waiting admission until a bed opens.
data.choice_2: Discharge him home today with hospice and an overnight aide, freeing the bed for the new admission tonight.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) emphasizing the patient’s informed, persistent preference to stay inpatient despite understanding home hospice supports, and (2) clarifying the competing justice-based need: the incoming referral has uncontrolled symptoms/no safe home option and no alternative inpatient bed in the region tonight. Also state that home hospice with overnight aide can meet the current patient’s needs with acceptable safety, to sharpen the tradeoff between respecting autonomy vs allocating scarce inpatient resources.

Make the value conflict explicit by clearly stating (1) the patient’s informed, stable preference to stay inpatient for perceived safety vs (2) the unit’s obligation to allocate a scarce hospice bed to another patient with urgent, unmanageable-at-home symptoms and no alternative support. Add brief details showing home hospice is feasible and safe (meds delivered, overnight aide confirmed) while inpatient care offers mainly reassurance, and clarify the incoming referral’s clinical urgency and lack of alternatives.

data.vignette:
A 72-year-old man with metastatic pancreatic cancer is admitted to a 6-bed inpatient hospice unit for pain control and caregiver exhaustion. After 48 hours, his pain and nausea are well-controlled on a stable regimen, he is eating small amounts, and he is alert and decisional. The hospice team explains that his current symptoms can be safely managed at home: a hospital bed has been delivered, a home hospice nurse can visit daily with 24/7 on-call coverage, medications will be delivered tonight, and an overnight aide has been confirmed for the next week. The patient demonstrates understanding by repeating the plan back and acknowledging that home hospice can meet his medical needs, but he persistently states he wants to stay inpatient because he feels safer in the unit and fears dying at home.

At the same time, the medical director receives an urgent referral from a 58-year-old woman with end-stage COPD who is in severe dyspnea and panic despite maximal outpatient medications. She lives alone in a third-floor walk-up, has no available caregiver, and emergency services have brought her to the ED twice today. Her symptoms are uncontrolled, she has no safe home option tonight, and there are no other inpatient hospice beds available in the region until tomorrow afternoon.

The unit has one bed, and keeping the current patient overnight would mean turning away the incoming referral or boarding her in a noisy ED without hospice-level symptom management.

choice_1.choice: Respect the current patient’s informed, persistent preference to remain inpatient overnight for reassurance, delaying discharge until the next day even though home hospice with overnight aide and medication delivery is in place.

choice_2.choice: Proceed with discharge of the current patient to home hospice tonight as planned, explaining the need to allocate the only inpatient hospice bed to the incoming patient with uncontrolled symptoms and no safe alternative, while offering extra home supports and immediate on-call nurse check-ins.
